scala: A high-level programming language that combines object-oriented and functional programming paradigms. It is designed to be concise and interoperable with Java.
oracle: A popular database management system known for its robustness and enterprise-level features, often used in large-scale applications.
hibernate: An open-source Java-based ORM (Object-Relational Mapping) framework that simplifies data handling by mapping Java objects to database tables.
cocoa: A native API for macOS and iOS development, providing a framework for building graphical user interfaces and other functionality.
osx: The former name of macOS, the operating system developed by Apple for its Mac computers, known for its Unix-based architecture.
sharepoint: A web-based collaborative platform by Microsoft, used for document management, storage, and team collaboration.
matlab: A high-level programming language and environment for numerical computing, widely used in engineering and scientific applications.
haskell: A purely functional programming language with strong static typing and lazy evaluation, often used for research and advanced programming tasks.
wordpress: A popular open-source content management system (CMS) used for creating websites and blogs, known for its flexibility and plugin ecosystem.
spring: A comprehensive Java-based framework for building enterprise applications, providing support for dependency injection, aspect-oriented programming, and more.
magento: An open-source e-commerce platform written in PHP, offering a flexible and feature-rich system for building online stores.
svn: Short for Subversion, a version control system that helps developers manage changes to source code over time.
ajax: A set of web development techniques for creating asynchronous web applications, enabling data exchange without refreshing the entire page.
bash: A Unix shell and command language, widely used for scripting and task automation in Linux and macOS environments.
excel: A spreadsheet software developed by Microsoft, used for data analysis, visualization, and computation.
linq: Language Integrated Query, a .NET library by Microsoft that provides query capabilities for C# and VB.NET, enabling operations on data collections.
qt: A cross-platform C++ framework for developing graphical user interfaces and applications.
drupal: An open-source content management system (CMS) used for building websites and applications, known for its flexibility and scalability.
apache: A widely-used open-source web server software that powers a significant portion of websites on the internet.
visual-studio: An integrated development environment (IDE) by Microsoft, used for developing software applications in various programming languages.
